results.title: Destinos: an introduction to Spanish
results.brief_description: A series of introductory Spanish language programmes, in the form of a long-running mystery drama about Don Fernando and the secrets of his past. Learn Spanish while the mystery takes you all over the Spanish speaking world. Each programme is structured carefully so that three kinds of Spanish are used. Conversational Spanish, which is spoken by the characters in the drama. The narrator’s Spanish, and the Spanish spoken by the instructor, Raquel, who breaks in periodically during the episode to explain and re-inforce particular language structures and grammar. In this series, you will learn about the Spanish speaking world, its culture, life and customs.

results.title: Destination Australia: the migrant story
results.creator_credit: Lisa Pennock, Immigration Museum and ScreenSound Australia
results.brief_description: A fascinating and comprehensive look at the history of immigration in Australia since 1901 combining excerpt footage from films, newsreels and commercials held within ScreenSound Australia’s Archives and photographs from private collections. The story begins with the Immigration Restriction Act of 1901 and the passing of the White Australia Policy. It continues through to the multiculturalism of the 1970s and the eventual phasing out of that most incongruous White Australia Policy, particularly in the light of Australia’s involvement with Vietnam and our acceptance of the Vietnamese boat people to our shores. Includes footage of child migration; Dunera boys and internees; displaced persons; Bonegilla - Australia’s first holding centre for arriving non-British migrants; 10 pound Poms and “Bring out a Briton” campaign; the Snowy Mountains Scheme; multicultural events as well as many great shots from the past of some of Australia’s historic moments (air raid on Darwin in 1943, the arrival of the Dunera), prominent citizens (Jack Lang, Arthur Calwell, Chips Rafferty) and well-known landscapes (Port Melbourne docks, Sydney Harbour). Introduced by Les Cassidy and narrated by Henri Szeps.

results.title: Destination Australia
results.creator_credit: Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A series of eight short programmes examining the role of migration in the development of Australia’s nationhood. The titles are: 1. “From gaol to gentry”. 1788-1840. 2. “The Golden land”. 1840-1900. 3. “Growing pains” 1901-1945. 4. “The Widening net”. 1945 onwards. 5. “White Australia policy”. 6. “Who’ll do the dirty work”. 7. “You keep juggling”. 8. “Foreigners”.

results.title: Desire
results.creator_credit: Emma-Kate Croghan, Kathy Shelper and Femme fatale
results.brief_description: In this short film by Emma-Kate Croghan a series of classic film noir tropes are cleverly strung together to make a riveting 10 minute story. A lonely laboratory worker (Michael Lake) becomes obsessed with a parcel which a beautiful and mysterious woman has left on a train. Will the object of his desires yield pleasures or tragedy? Winner Best Direction New Films Award and Australian Cinematographers Society Award at 1993 St Kilda Film Festival. With sound editing by Stavros Efthymiou.

results.title: Designing women
results.creator_credit: Roger MacDougall, Central Office of Information and Merlin Films
results.brief_description: The adventures of Anna and Tom, a pair of newly-weds who are unpacking their wedding presents and thinking about furnishing their new flat. The couple each make a wish, and two angels appear: one named “Design” and the other named “Arty”. Arty introduces the couple to showy art-deco style furnishings but Anna and Tom’s common sense wins over and they choose Design’s well-made and practical “style”. This film offers the viewer three questions: Does it work? Is it well-made? Is it attractive? Hmmm.

results.title: Designed for success: programmed for what?
results.creator_credit: Peter Engebretsen, Bank of New South Wales, CES and Scottcom
results.brief_description: Through the eyes of a teenager, explores some of the personal considerations involved in finding a job. Entertaining approach to a difficult question using good clever dialogue and innovative visuals. Cast includes Michael Smith, Basil Clarke, Anne Lambert, Peter Colville, David Wood, Des Mangan.

holdings.name: VHS, Audio Cassette, Text; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: Design for irrigation: reconstructure of the home farm. Pt 2
results.brief_description: Describes a plan for more efficient irrigation of an old property. The chief problem is poorly designed and maintained supply and distribution ditches. In some areas, trees are small and deformed through lack of water - in others flooding is so bad that neighbours complain of seepage. Suggests immediate plan requiring cleaning and modification of supply and drainage channels. The long term plan put forward suggests the use of concrete channels and underground pipelines, which would result in perfect water distribution and in this case, room for more trees in place of open channels.

results.title: Design for irrigation. [Parts 1 & 2]
results.brief_description: Shows that a proper plan of irrigation is essential when planting new orchads. The example in the film is a new block of slightly sloping land which is to be planted with fruit trees. A model of the block shows the contours, and the method of ploughing, irrigation and planing which should be carried out in relation to the contour lines.

results.title: Desert people
results.creator_credit: William L. Claiborne and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: Shows the importance of water to desert people. Compares the Tuaregs, nomadic people constantly in search of water, with the Hajputs, who are cultivators, running water through an ancient irrigation system by camel power and natural flow. This film has no English dialogue, the images speak for themselves. However, you can hear the Desert people in their native tongue.
